Now, we need to set up the figure we’ll be plotting our animation on.
Running the next cell will produce a blank figure in the jupyter notebook. This is expected since we’ve only created a blank figure to plot on, but haven’t actually plotted anything yet.

ax = fig.add_axes([0, 0, 1, 1])  # span the whole figure

First, we set out dpi to be 100. This is technically not necessary at this point in creating the animation, but we’re going to use it to set the size of the figure. Since we’re plotting images, we want to make sure that the figure size is the same size as the images we’re plotting.
Next, we’re going to figure out what our figsize should be based on the dpi and the size of the images we’re about to plot.
tuple(t / dpi for t in Image.open(im_dir + im_paths[0]).size)
divides each dimension of the size of the image by the intended dpi and then returns the result as a tuple. We then use that tuple to create our figsize.

Since we’re working with data represented by latitude and longitude coordinates, we’re going to set up our figure and axes using

ax = plt.axes(projection=ccrs.PlateCarree())
ax.coastlines()

Now that we have our figure and axes set up, we can plot the initial frame of our animation.

vmin = t.min().values
vmax = t.max().values
levels = 30

# create initial plot that we will update
t[0, :, :].plot.contourf(
    ax=ax,
    transform=ccrs.PlateCarree(),
    vmin=vmin,
    vmax=vmax,
    levels=levels,
    cmap="inferno",
    cbar_kwargs={
        "location": "bottom",
    },
)

In addition to plotting the initial frame, we also set up the colorbar. In order for every frame of the animation to use the same colorbar, we need to create the colorbar before we create the animation.

Now that we have our initial frame, we need to create an update function that will update the data in the plot to create each frame of the animation. This function will be passed in as an argument to

, which is the frame number of the animation. The argument

# create function to update plot
def animate(i):
    # Plot the new frame
    t[i, :, :].plot.contourf(

        transform=ccrs.PlateCarree(),
        vmin=vmin,
        vmax=vmax,
        levels=levels,
        cmap="inferno",
